intro: Plagiobothrys collinus var. ursinus, commonly known as the Sierra sand verbena, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a low-growing perennial herb with slender, branched stems and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically blooms in spring, producing pink to purple flowers that attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It thrives in dry, sandy soils and is often found in chaparral and coastal scrub habitats. The species is characterized by its distinctive leaf morphology and is part of the Geraniaceae family.
